1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This standard covers Hawalah transactions that involve a change of debtor,  This standard covers Hawalah transactions that involve a change of debtor, 
i.e. transfer of debt. The scope of this standard does not cover banking i.e. transfer of debt. The scope of this standard does not cover banking

of debt).of debt).
2. Definition of Hawalah2. Definition of Hawalah
 Hawalah of debt is the transfer of debt from the transferor ( Hawalah of debt is the transfer of debt from the transferor ( MuheelMuheel ) to the ) to the 
payer (payer ( Muhal AlaihiMuhal Alaihi ). The transfer of right, on the other hand, is a replacement ). The transfer of right, on the other hand, is a replacement 
of a creditor with another creditor. The transfer of debt differ from transfer of a creditor with another creditor. The transfer of debt differ from transfer 
of right in that in transfer of debt a debtor is replaced by another debtor, of right in that in transfer of debt a debtor is replaced by another debtor, 
whereas in a transfer of right a creditor is replaced by another creditor.whereas in a transfer of right a creditor is replaced by another creditor.

courtesy and is not a contract of sale. It is permitted in order to courtesy and is not a contract of sale. It is permitted in order to 
facilitate payments and recovery.facilitate payments and recovery.

potential payer is known to be solvent and a person who honours potential payer is known to be solvent and a person who honours 
payments. This is because Hawalah benefits the creditor and gives payments. This is because Hawalah benefits the creditor and gives 
relief to the debtor. If the financial status and creditworthiness of relief to the debtor. If the financial status and creditworthiness of 
the potential payer are unknown, then Hawalah becomes the potential payer are unknown, then Hawalah becomes MubahMubah  
(permissible).(permissible).

Wisdom of Making Salam PermissibleWisdom of Making Salam Permissible
The wisdom of making Salam permissible lies in the fact that Salam The wisdom of making Salam permissible lies in the fact that Salam 
facilitates a type of financing for people in need of it. In particular, farmers, facilitates a type of financing for people in need of it. In particular, farmers,

4304307. Distinction between Ju’alah and Ijarah7. Distinction between Ju’alah and Ijarah
 Ju’alah is distinguished from Ijarah on the following grounds: Ju’alah is distinguished from Ijarah on the following grounds:
7/1 Ju’alah is valid despite uncertainty of work deeming the determination 7/1 Ju’alah is valid despite uncertainty of work deeming the determination 
of the required result by the offeror as sufficient.of the required result by the offeror as sufficient.
7/2 Ju’alah does not require acceptance.7/2 Ju’alah does not require acceptance.
7/3 Entitlement to compensation depends on completion of work and 7/3 Entitlement to compensation depends on completion of work and 
delivery of result.delivery of result.
7/4 Ju’alah is valid even if the other party is not known.7/4 Ju’alah is valid even if the other party is not known.
7/5 As a rule, Ju’alah is terminable, while Ijarah is binding.7/5 As a rule, Ju’alah is terminable, while Ijarah is binding.

Permissibility of Ju’alahPermissibility of Ju’alah
Ju’alah contract is permissible according to the majority of the Fuqaha Ju’alah contract is permissible according to the majority of the Fuqaha 
on the basis of the Qur`an, the Sunnah, Ijma’ (consensus of Fuqaha) and on the basis of the Qur`an, the Sunnah, Ijma’ (consensus of Fuqaha) and

 This standard covers possession in contracts and what acts as a constructive  This standard covers possession in contracts and what acts as a constructive 
substitute for it (constructive possession). It elaborates the mode of its substitute for it (constructive possession). It elaborates the mode of its 
realisation in immovable and movable property as well as in things that realisation in immovable and movable property as well as in things that 
are ascertained and those established as a liability by description. The are ascertained and those established as a liability by description. The 
standard also identifies the person responsible for its costs (maintenance standard also identifies the person responsible for its costs (maintenance 
and expenses) in various types of contracts along with their modern and expenses) in various types of contracts along with their modern

possession in set-offs, as these have their specific standards.possession in set-offs, as these have their specific standards.

588588Statement of the StandardStatement of the Standard
1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This Standard covers the basic Shari’ah rulings relating to Concession  This Standard covers the basic Shari’ah rulings relating to Concession 
Contracts for utilization, construction or management of projects, and Contracts for utilization, construction or management of projects, and 
provides guidance to Institutions on application of such contracts. It does provides guidance to Institutions on application of such contracts. It does 
not cover legal or consensual concession rights, which are subsidiary not cover legal or consensual concession rights, which are subsidiary 
rights. This standard does not cover franchises as it should be dealt with rights. This standard does not cover franchises as it should be dealt with 
by a separate standard.by a separate standard.
2. Definition of Concession2. Definition of Concession
 Concession in this context refers to the act of an authorized party granting  Concession in this context refers to the act of an authorized party granting 
another party the right of utilizing, constructing or managing a project another party the right of utilizing, constructing or managing a project 
for agreed upon consideration.for agreed upon consideration.

1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This standard covers syndicated financing operations, whether those  This standard covers syndicated financing operations, whether those 
arranged among Institutions, or between them and conventional banks, arranged among Institutions, or between them and conventional banks, 
and the Institution-agent relationships relating to such operations.and the Institution-agent relationships relating to such operations.
2. Definition of Syndicated Financing2. Definition of Syndicated Financing
 It refers to the participation of a group of institutions in a joint financing  It refers to the participation of a group of institutions in a joint financing 
operation through one of the Shari’ah-compliant modes of financing. operation through one of the Shari’ah-compliant modes of financing. 
The accounts of the syndicated financing operation are kept independent The accounts of the syndicated financing operation are kept independent 
from the accounts of the participating Institutions.from the accounts of the participating Institutions.
3. Projects Financed Through Syndication3. Projects Financed Through Syndication
 Syndicated financing should be channeled towards investment activities  Syndicated financing should be channeled towards investment activities 
that are permissible in Shari’ah. It should not be totally or partially directed that are permissible in Shari’ah. It should not be totally or partially directed 
towards projects that encounter Shari’ah restriction or constitute Riba.towards projects that encounter Shari’ah restriction or constitute Riba.

The Shari’ah Basis for the StandardThe Shari’ah Basis for the Standard
 ■It is permissible for the Institutions to provide banking services that do It is permissible for the Institutions to provide banking services that do 
not involve interest-based lending and borrowing, because such services not involve interest-based lending and borrowing, because such services 
serve a permissible interest of the clients.serve a permissible interest of the clients.
 ■Institutions may charge fees for providing banking services, because the Institutions may charge fees for providing banking services, because the 
fees so charged constitute a remuneration which the Institutions deserve fees so charged constitute a remuneration which the Institutions deserve 
for the tasks they perform, since it is permissible in Shari’ah to get reward for the tasks they perform, since it is permissible in Shari’ah to get reward 
for performing tasks that result in permissible benefits to others.for performing tasks that result in permissible benefits to others.
 ■The fee charged by the institutions may be a lump sum amount or a percen-The fee charged by the institutions may be a lump sum amount or a percen-
tage of the value of the service, because when the percentage remuneration tage of the value of the service, because when the percentage remuneration 
is calculated it becomes like the lump sum amount.is calculated it becomes like the lump sum amount.

2. Definition and Types of Gharar2. Definition and Types of Gharar
2/1 Gharar is a state of uncertainty that exists when the process of con-2/1 Gharar is a state of uncertainty that exists when the process of con-
cluding a transaction involves an unknown aspect. In other words, cluding a transaction involves an unknown aspect. In other words,

FinancingFinancing
Financing takes place only when one of the two objects of the transaction Financing takes place only when one of the two objects of the transaction 
is deferred such as loan, discounting of bills, simple credit, Murabahah, is deferred such as loan, discounting of bills, simple credit, Murabahah, 
Salam and Istisna’a. Financing may not take place in Salam and Istisna’a. Financing may not take place in suretyshipssuretyships , letters of , letters of 
guarantee, letters of documentary credits and bank acceptances. Therefore, guarantee, letters of documentary credits and bank acceptances. Therefore, 
the term financing is more special than the term credit. That is to say, any the term financing is more special than the term credit. That is to say, any 
financing is credit, but any credit does not always lead to financing.financing is credit, but any credit does not always lead to financing.

for this purpose (the indebted-current account) up to a certain maximum for this purpose (the indebted-current account) up to a certain maximum 
limit which constitutes the amount of the loan, and within a specific period. limit which constitutes the amount of the loan, and within a specific period.

terest and is considered as Riba (usury).terest and is considered as Riba (usury).

11381138Statement of the StandardStatement of the Standard
1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This Standard covers profit, its validity in Shari’ah and rules and methods  This Standard covers profit, its validity in Shari’ah and rules and methods 
of calculating and distributing it. It also explains who is entitled to profit of calculating and distributing it. It also explains who is entitled to profit 
earned from the financing and investment activities of the institutions. earned from the financing and investment activities of the institutions. 
This Standard does not cover profit distribution in investment accounts This Standard does not cover profit distribution in investment accounts 
because that is provided in a separate Standard.because that is provided in a separate Standard.
2. Definition of Profit and Methods of Calculation2. Definition of Profit and Methods of Calculation
 In the context of this Standard, Profit means the amount generated in  In the context of this Standard, Profit means the amount generated in

1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This Standard covers the Shari’ah rules and requirements for Irrigation  This Standard covers the Shari’ah rules and requirements for Irrigation 
Partnership (Musaqat) and its applications in the activities of Islamic Partnership (Musaqat) and its applications in the activities of Islamic 
financial institutions. It does not cover other forms of agricultural part-financial institutions. It does not cover other forms of agricultural part-
nership as they have separate Shari’ah standards dedicated to them.nership as they have separate Shari’ah standards dedicated to them.
2. Definition of Irrigation Partnership (Musaqat)2. Definition of Irrigation Partnership (Musaqat)
 A contract between the owner of an orchard or its usufruct and a worker  A contract between the owner of an orchard or its usufruct and a worker 
(irrigator) agreeing to share the produce according to specific ratios (irrigator) agreeing to share the produce according to specific ratios 
stipulated at the time of contract. stipulated at the time of contract. 
3. Permissibility and Description of the Contract3. Permissibility and Description of the Contract
 Irrigation Partnership (Musaqat) is a permissible contract that becomes  Irrigation Partnership (Musaqat) is a permissible contract that becomes 
binding on commencement of the work or if mutually agreed between binding on commencement of the work or if mutually agreed between 
the two parties not to terminate the contract before its expiry.the two parties not to terminate the contract before its expiry.
4. Elements of Irrigation Partnership4. Elements of Irrigation Partnership
4/1 Offer and acceptance should be exchanged explicitly or implicitly by 4/1 Offer and acceptance should be exchanged explicitly or implicitly by 
means of a recognised form of indication.means of a recognised form of indication.
4/2 Each of the two parties should be legally competent.4/2 Each of the two parties should be legally competent.
4/3 The relevant trees should be identified, arable (productive), and in 4/3 The relevant trees should be identified, arable (productive), and in 
need of irrigation and plant husbandry.need of irrigation and plant husbandry.
5. Conditions of Validity (Prerequisites)5. Conditions of Validity (Prerequisites)
5/1 The contract should stipulate for each party a predetermined, defined, 5/1 The contract should stipulate for each party a predetermined, defined, 
indivisible share of the produce.indivisible share of the produce.
5/2 The work should be restricted to the husbandry of the crop and trees. 5/2 The work should be restricted to the husbandry of the crop and trees. 
The owner may not (in this contract) demand any additional work The owner may not (in this contract) demand any additional work 
from the worker (irrigator).from the worker (irrigator).

12021202Statement of the StandardStatement of the Standard
1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This Standard covers options to revoke contracts due to reasons of defect,  This Standard covers options to revoke contracts due to reasons of defect, 
deal fragmentation and breach of description. It does not cover options deal fragmentation and breach of description. It does not cover options 
to revoke arising from breach of trust (dishonest inducement, deception to revoke arising from breach of trust (dishonest inducement, deception 
and overcharging) or options of due diligence (cooling-off options, and and overcharging) or options of due diligence (cooling-off options, and 
options to revoke due to non-payment) as they have separate Shari’ah options to revoke due to non-payment) as they have separate Shari’ah 
standards dedicated to them.standards dedicated to them.
2. Option to Revoke Due to Defect2. Option to Revoke Due to Defect
2/1 Definition2/1 Definition
 It is the option of a buyer to revoke or continue with the contract  It is the option of a buyer to revoke or continue with the contract 
arising from a hidden defect that the buyer did not notice at the arising from a hidden defect that the buyer did not notice at the 
time of contract.time of contract.
2/2 Conditions applicable to options to revoke due to defect2/2 Conditions applicable to options to revoke due to defect
 An option to revoke due to defect is subject to the following conditions: An option to revoke due to defect is subject to the following conditions:
2/2/1 Appearance of a material defect in the subject matter of the 2/2/1 Appearance of a material defect in the subject matter of the 
contract.contract.
 A material defect is a defect that renders the item defective  A material defect is a defect that renders the item defective 
according to custom, makes it unfit for purpose or diminishes according to custom, makes it unfit for purpose or diminishes 
its value.its value.
2/2/2 The defective item being incapable of repair except by incurring 2/2/2 The defective item being incapable of repair except by incurring 
cost.cost.
2/2/3 The buyer being unaware of the hidden defect at the time of 2/2/3 The buyer being unaware of the hidden defect at the time of 
contract, irrespective of the seller’s awareness of the defect at contract, irrespective of the seller’s awareness of the defect at 
the time of the contract.the time of the contract.
2/2/4 The contract not containing a clause excluding the seller’s li-2/2/4 The contract not containing a clause excluding the seller’s li-
ability for defect (ability for defect ( Bay’ al-Bara`ahBay’ al-Bara`ah - sale on the basis of as is - sale on the basis of as is

2/2/5 The hidden defect not being caused by the buyer.2/2/5 The hidden defect not being caused by the buyer.

 Options to revoke due to defect exist in commutative financial con- Options to revoke due to defect exist in commutative financial con-

of debt by payment in kind and gift conditional upon receipt of of debt by payment in kind and gift conditional upon receipt of

order.order.

1. Scope of the Standard1. Scope of the Standard
 This Standard covers the stipulation of revocation of valid and binding  This Standard covers the stipulation of revocation of valid and binding 
contracts and the causes and consequences of and impediments to such contracts and the causes and consequences of and impediments to such 
revocation. It does not cover the expiry of contracts at the end of their revocation. It does not cover the expiry of contracts at the end of their 
contractual terms or nullification owing to the absence of a condition contractual terms or nullification owing to the absence of a condition 
required by the Shari’ah.required by the Shari’ah.
2. Definition of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke2. Definition of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke
 Revocation by exercise of a cooling-off option refers to the termination  Revocation by exercise of a cooling-off option refers to the termination 
of a valid and binding contract by virtue of a stipulation in the contract of a valid and binding contract by virtue of a stipulation in the contract 
giving one of the parties the option to revoke the contract.giving one of the parties the option to revoke the contract.
3. Form of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke3. Form of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke
 A cooling-off option to revoke can be stipulated in the contract in any  A cooling-off option to revoke can be stipulated in the contract in any 
form that indicates it, and it is not required to use any specific word with form that indicates it, and it is not required to use any specific word with 
the meaning of revocation.the meaning of revocation.
4. Permissibility of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke4. Permissibility of Cooling-Off Options to Revoke
4/1 It is permissible for both parties to stipulate an option for one or both 4/1 It is permissible for both parties to stipulate an option for one or both 
of them to revoke the contract in specific situations agreed in the of them to revoke the contract in specific situations agreed in the 
contract, without violating Shari’ah rules.contract, without violating Shari’ah rules.
4/2 Revocation by exercise of a cooling-off option is valid if its causes 4/2 Revocation by exercise of a cooling-off option is valid if its causes 
exist, its conditions are satisfied and there are no impediments. It is exist, its conditions are satisfied and there are no impediments. It is 
invalid if its causes do not exist, any of its conditions is not satisfied, invalid if its causes do not exist, any of its conditions is not satisfied, 
if there is an impediment or it is contrary to Shari’ah.if there is an impediment or it is contrary to Shari’ah.
5. Causes Triggering Revocation Rights 5. Causes Triggering Revocation Rights 
 The cause that triggers the cooling-off option is the existence of one of  The cause that triggers the cooling-off option is the existence of one of 
the situations stipulated in the contract, the occurrence of which gives the situations stipulated in the contract, the occurrence of which gives 
one or both parties a conditional right to revoke.one or both parties a conditional right to revoke.

■ ■ The four impediments to the exercise of cooling-off options are based The four impediments to the exercise of cooling-off options are based 
variously on the following rationale: (I) Revocation would contradict the variously on the following rationale: (I) Revocation would contradict the 
basic elements of the contract which have been validly established; or (II) basic elements of the contract which have been validly established; or (II) 
revocation would contradict consent implied by conduct (implied terms revocation would contradict consent implied by conduct (implied terms 
have the same legal effect as express ones); or (III) revocation is impossible have the same legal effect as express ones); or (III) revocation is impossible 
because the term of the contract has expired; or (IV) the subject matter of because the term of the contract has expired; or (IV) the subject matter of 
the option to revoke is deemed by law to have ceased to exist.the option to revoke is deemed by law to have ceased to exist.
